entry.title: Combined summary - On adaptor security (in protocols)
entry.summary: In recent discussions among members of the bitcoin-dev mailing list, there were disagreements over the usefulness of single-signer adaptors. One member, Waxwing, claimed that these adaptors had no practical application since they did not provide a way to create enforcement that the publication of signature on a pre-defined message would reveal a secret. However, another member, LL, disagreed and suggested that these adaptors could be useful in revealing secrets.LL argued that if someone holds a secret key for X and creates a signature adaptor with encryption key Y for a message m without creating any further signatures on m, any published signature on m necessarily reveals the secret on Y to them. LL believes this is useful and has already been used for years by DLCs in production. In addition, LL proposed a general proof against all secure Schnorr signing schemes in the ROM by extending the ROM forwarding approach from Aumayer et al to all "tweak" operations on elements that go into the Schnorr challenge hash, such as the public key and nonce.AdamISZ also discussed the security of using signature adaptors in two-party swapping and multiparty swaps. While there is already substantial work regarding the security of adaptors from 2019-2021, AdamISZ's analysis focused on scenarios with multiple adaptors or signing sessions with the same adaptor. Lloyd Fournier responded to the post, arguing against AdamISZ's claim that single signer adaptors are useless, citing their usefulness in revealing secrets. Fournier also suggested a general proof against all secure Schnorr signing schemes in the ROM by extending the ROM forwarding approach from Aumayer et al to all "tweak" operations on elements that go into the Schnorr challenge hash. This would allow proving all variants secure for past and present schemes in one go. The experts in the field discuss and propose various proofs and approaches to ensure the security of Schnorr-like schemes, including the application of bijective maps and tweaking operations.In a separate conversation between AdamISZ and Lloyd Fournier, they concluded that single key signature adaptors in isolation are basically useless in a Bitcoin context but could be useful when combined with another locking condition on the UTXO, such as another pubkey lock (e.g. op_checksigadd/op_checkmultisig). They also discussed the canonical adaptor-based swap and its potential variant. Overall, the conversations revolve around the security and usefulness of signature adaptors in various scenarios, including two-party swapping and multiparty swaps. The experts in the field discuss and propose various proofs and approaches to ensure the security of Schnorr-like schemes, including the application of bijective maps and tweaking operations. They also acknowledge the practical use of single signer adaptors in transaction signatures and other implementations.
